NewsDetail.BodyCopy:
"I will show unto them their weakness"

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Sometimes our best students don’t start out that way. And students can say the same regarding their favorite teachers. I would like to share the story of Sam (not his real name), a former student of mine. First, I offer my own perspective on this unusual student, as expressed in a recommendation letter I eventually wrote on his behalf for a high school teaching position.

My Letter of Recommendation for Sam

 Sam is an interesting case in that he didn’t start out as an outstanding student, but over time he transformed himself into one of my best. It’s one thing to be a good student. It’s quite another thing (and perhaps more impressive) to become a good student. A teacher who has experienced this process first hand will be a real asset to his school and to his students, since this is what teaching is all about.

In the first course he took from me (Spanish 339-Introduction to Literary Analysis), Sam was about average, earning a B-. He enrolled in another course (Spanish 441-Masterpieces of Spanish Literature) the following semester, wherein he did very little, had a lot of absences and effectively withdrew from the course. I believe I gave him a D. Making no excuses, Sam admitted that he should have done better, and he vowed to improve the next time around. Retaking SPAN 441, Sam had perfect attendance, was always prepared for class, and was one of the most proactive students in terms of participation. In the course of our discussions of the literary readings I was repeatedly impressed with his attention to detail and the quality and depth of his insights. He ended up with an unequivocal A in the course. He was cheerful, enthusiastic, and highly motivated, not for the sake of a grade, evidently, but truly to learn. Somehow he had come to terms with his shortcomings and turned them into strengths.

Sam has a lot to offer as a teacher. That last semester he demonstrated a sound mastery of Spanish and the ability to grapple with difficult literary readings. However, I think his mastery of the content is less interesting than the improvement he made as a student from one semester to the next. I attribute his success in the course to his humility and a simple act of will power. Sam must have learned something about himself and about the nature of learning that will serve him well in his dealings with all kinds of students over the course of his career: he will be able to identify with the average students as well as the highly motivated, and to bring out the best effort in everyone. 

Sam’s Point of View

Sam’s own perspective on his transformation is illuminating. I find it interesting because of what it reveals about my own process of transformation in becoming a better teacher. It turns out that Sam wasn’t the only one who made a bad first impression. In the end, I was “wrong” about Sam, and he was “wrong” about me. Somehow it all turned out okay in the end, not in spite of the disconnect, I think, but (at least in part) because of it. Here are Sam’s words, which I quote from multiple installments of an email exchange:

I know we had a rocky time starting out, but I really felt like I matured and learned so much in your class. I think that you feel that way too. [. . .] Honestly, I didn’t really like you when I first took you for 339. My first week in class you told me that I would fail academically because I had not read the syllabus yet. However, with time I realized that you care more than I had thought. You came across really dry, but you grew on me and I feel like I might have grown on you some. After 441, I was sad that you didn’t teach more classes. [. . .] I really did enjoy both 339 and 441. It was also interesting for me to see you as a teacher try new things and tweak your style. That made me respect you more. [. . .] The interesting thing to me is I had so much fun in that class that I worked hard in. Something that a lot of people don’t know is I didn’t like Spanish in High School. My last Spanish teacher told me to never take Spanish again. [. . .] However, I was sent to LA as a Spanish speaking missionary. I loved it and I loved the language and people. I am really excited to help someone else’s school experience be better than mine. You surprised me and made college much better. I want to do that.

Becoming

I like this story because it’s about becoming. Elder Oaks taught, “In contrast to the institutions of the world, which teach us to know something, the gospel of Jesus Christ challenges us to become something” (“The Challenge to Become,” Ensign, Nov 2000, 32). My experience with Sam helps me to see that my role isn’t just to help students know things; the time we spend with students in our classrooms and in our offices needs to help them—and us—become. The two of us became something better together through a long and often difficult process. I witnessed Sam’s growth, just as he witnessed mine, and each of us his own. I think Sam’s story reads well at this “Disciple Preparation Center.” We’re not perfect, Sam and I, but with humility and a bit of help from the Lord, we somehow managed to bless one another’s lives.

And if men come unto me I will show unto them their weakness. I give unto men weakness that they may be humble; and my grace is sufficient for all men that humble themselves before me; for if they humble themselves before me, and have faith in me, then will I make weak things become strong unto them. (Ether 12:27)
